Graphical abstract This review offers insights into the design of Co-based catalysts for the acidic oxygen evolution reaction in proton exchange membrane water electrolyzers environments, emphasizing strategies to enhance their activity and stability. Proton exchange membrane water electrolyzers (PEMWEs) are pivotal for efficient hydrogen production due to their high energy efficiency and ability to operate at high current densities, making them ideally suited for integration with renewable energy sources. Cobalt (Co)-based nanomaterials, characterized by diverse oxidation states, tunable electronic spin states, and hybrid orbitals, have emerged as promising non-noble metal alternatives to platinum group catalysts for accelerating the anodic oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Based on their inherent properties, this review provides a comprehensive overview of the latest developments in Co-based nanomaterials for acidic OER. The review begins by introducing the operational principles of PEMWEs, the underlying catalytic mechanisms, and the critical design considerations for OER catalysts. It then explores strategies to enhance the activity and stability of Co-based catalysts for acidic OER in PEMWEs, including the incorporation of corrosion-resistant metals or dispersion on acid-resistant supports to increase active surface area and stability; utilization of geometric structural engineering to improve structural integrity and active site efficiency; the optimization of reaction mechanisms to fine-tune catalytic pathways for enhanced stability and performance. The performance degradation mechanisms and metal leaching analysis for Co-based catalysts in PEMWE are also clarified. Finally, this review not only outlines the key challenges associated with Co-based catalysts for acidic OER but also proposes potential strategies to overcome these limitations, offering a roadmap for future advancements and practical implementation of PEMWE technology. Keywords Proton exchange membrane water electrolyzer Cobalt Oxygen evolution reaction Hydrogen Water electrolysis 1 Introduction Proton exchange membrane water electrolyzers (PEMWEs), operating in acidic environments, present several advantages for hydrogen production, such as high energy efficiency, rapid response times, compact design, and the ability to operate at elevated current densities, rendering them ideal for industrial applications (Fig. 1 a) [1–4]. As crucial components of advanced energy systems, PEMWE modules play a vital role in effective energy storage and conversion, while providing crucial synergy with renewable energy sources, thus bolstering the stability and sustainability of the energy grid (Fig. 1b) [5]. Within PEMWEs, the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) at the anode and the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) at the cathode are key processes [6,7]. The OER, a complex protons-electrons coupling reaction with inherently slow kinetics [8–10], is identified as the rate-limiting step in PEMWE operation [11]. Consequently, extensive research focuses on developing catalysts that can improve the OER kinetics in acidic conditions, thereby boosting the overall efficiency of water splitting. To meet the demands of industrial PEMWE, OER catalysts are required to demonstrate long-term durability under harsh acidic conditions and high current densities. Industrial benchmarks typically require stable operation for over 1000 h, with long-term targets exceeding 5000–10,000 h at current densities of ≥1 A cm−2. These stringent criteria ensure consistent hydrogen output, reduce system downtime, and lower overall operational costs. The durability of such systems is influenced by factors including the efficiency of the electrolysis process, the design and configuration of the electrolytic cells, and specific operational parameters [12,13]. As such, the development of catalysts that maintain high stability during OER in acidic conditions is another critical focus of ongoing research efforts. This pursuit is crucial for achieving long-term, reliable operation in industrial applications of water electrolysis. The catalytic activation of the OER in acidic environments is largely reliant on noble metals, primarily because of their optimal binding energy with crucial oxygen intermediates [14]. Several reviews have documented substantial advancements in noble metal-based nanomaterials for OER in PEMWE systems [15–19], observing a consistent activity trend of Ru > Ir > Pd in 0.1 M H2SO4 at 80 °C. However, despite their high catalytic activity, these noble metals encounter significant stability challenges. In harsh acidic environments and at high anodic potentials, even the most advanced Ir- and Ru-based catalysts suffer from corrosion, dissolution, structural reconstruction, and eventual degradation. Overpotentials are reported to range from 190 to 250 mV at 10 mA cm−2, but their durability is often limited to just 2–30 h of operation. As an example, Ru-based catalysts develop RuO4 films at the OER onset potential, leading to dissolution in the acidic medium and resulting in structural degradation and catalyst deactivation. This underscores the urgent need for the development of more robust and durable catalyst designs to overcome these significant durability challenges [20–23]. Additionally, the scarcity and high prices of noble metals, currently around US$9523 per kg for Ru and US$60,670 per kg for Ir, pose substantial economic challenges [24]. This combination of scarcity and high cost represents a significant barrier to the large-scale industrial implementation of noble metal-based PEMWE systems for widespread hydrogen production. The urgency for alternative, more cost-effective materials is highlighted by these economic constraints, driving the need for research into viable substitutes that maintain catalytic efficiency without the prohibitive expenses associated with noble metals. Significant efforts have been made to reduce the reliance on noble metals in OER catalysts, focusing on enhancing mass activity and stability while also cutting costs [25–30]. These strategies include the development of single-atom noble metal catalysts, which maximize catalytic efficiency by utilizing each atom, thereby minimizing material usage [31,32]. Another approach involves alloying noble metals with other elements, which merges the beneficial properties of different metals to boost catalytic performance and stability while decreasing the amount of noble metal required [33]. Additionally, the design of catalysts using more abundant transition metals as alternatives to noble metals shows great promise, offering high activity at a lower cost and paving the way for more cost-effective OER catalyst solutions [34–37]. Cobalt (Co)-based nanomaterials, with their diverse oxidation states, variable electronic spin states, and tunable hybrid orbitals, are emerging as promising candidates for the OER in acidic environments. Economically, Co is substantially more affordable than precious metals like Ru or Ir, costing approximately $25 per kg, making it an attractive alternative for large-scale applications. Performance-wise, as illustrated in Fig. 1(c), Co-based catalysts occupy a near-optimal position on the volcano plot derived from theoretical calculations of the OER Gibbs free energy barrier for intermediates (ΔG *O − ΔG *OH), suggesting their advantageous adsorption/desorption properties for efficient acidic OER [38]. This indicates theoretically superior reaction kinetics in comparison to other widely investigated Mn-based catalysts [39]. Regarding stability, Co2+ and Co3+ are stable in acidic and neutral conditions within pH ranges of 0–8 and 0–3, respectively, at higher potentials [40]. This suggests that cobalt compounds such as cobalt phosphides (CoP) and cobalt oxides (e.g., Co3O4) exhibit corrosion resistance and can remain stable under acidic conditions. In contrast, cobalt-based hydroxides (Co(OH)2) and oxyhydroxides (CoOOH) are more stable in higher pH ranges, making them better suited for alkaline OER applications. Structurally, Co ions typically adopt an octahedral coordination model, where the Co 3d orbitals split into five sub-orbitals: dx 2− y 2, dz 2, dxz , dyz , and dxy . The dx 2− y 2 and dz 2 orbitals exhibit two-fold degeneracy (eg), while the dxz , dyz , and dxy orbitals exhibit three-fold degeneracy (t2g) (Fig. 1d) [41]. The flexibility in the electronic spin states of Co-based catalysts, coupled with their varying oxidation states, allows for significant control over their interactions with oxygen intermediates and the adjustment of the thermodynamic energy for O2 molecule formation [42]. For example, Co3+ (3d 6) can exhibit two distinct spin-state configurations: a low-spin state (t2g 6eg 0) and a high-spin state (t2g 4eg 2), which can be tuned by modifying the coordination symmetry, which affects the bonding and antibonding ability with oxygen intermediates (Fig. 1e and f) [43,44]. Among various Co-based catalysts, spinel Co3O4 has been widely studied and recognized as a promising candidate for acidic OER due to its unique structural and electronic properties [45,46]. Its spinel crystal structure offers both tetrahedral (Co2+) and octahedral (Co3+) coordination sites, which enables favorable modulation of the electronic structure, especially the spin state of Co ions, to enhance the both activity and stability. This feature facilitates optimized adsorption and desorption behavior of oxygen intermediates which is critical for improving the OER kinetics. Besides, Co3O4 exhibits relatively higher thermodynamic stability under electrochemical conditions compared to other Co-based oxides or hydroxides (e.g., CoO or Co(OH)2), making it more resistant to corrosion and phase transformation in acidic environments. Furthermore, the spinel framework can tolerate moderate cation substitution or defect engineering, offering a versatile platform for performance optimization through doping or nanostructuring strategies. Tables S1–S3 show the performance comparison of Co-based catalysts for acidic OER compared with other metal-based catalysts in PEMWEs. The relatively low overpotential and enhanced durability make Co-based catalysts highly suitable for application in PEMWE technologies. Despite significant progress in enhancing the activity of Co-based catalysts through strategies such as expanding the active surface area and modulating the electronic structure to improve intrinsic activity [47], the stability of Co-based materials for acidic OER is still a challenge. Common deactivation mechanisms can be broadly categorized as catalyst dissolution (chemical, oxidative, or reductive) [48], phase transformation [49–51], phase segregation or structural rearrangement, agglomeration, surface passivation, and catalyst detachment from the substrate electrode [52,53]. Such degradation mechanisms are often overlooked in a three-electrode set-up, as these evaluations are typically performed under relatively mild and static conditions. However, when transitioning to a practical PEMWE, the more confined architecture and elevated operating temperatures significantly intensify catalyst deactivation. These issues have been thoroughly discussed in several reviews [1,19,54,55]. Pourbaix diagram known as an electrochemical potential-pH diagram, illustrated in Fig. 1(g), is a tool to help depict the stability and corrosion behaviors of metals or compounds in aqueous solutions [40], providing insights into electrochemical behaviors and aiding in the design of corrosion-resistant materials suitable for acidic conditions. Beyond the degradation of catalysts, several additional factors contribute to performance deterioration in practical PEMWE systems. These include membrane aging due to radical attack and mechanical stress, delamination at the catalyst layer-membrane interface, and metal ion contamination originating from bipolar plate corrosion or other system components. Moreover, improper water management may cause flooding or drying, both of which negatively impact ionic conductivity and mass transport [56–58]. These factors collectively highlight the necessity of evaluating catalyst stability under realistic PEMWE operating conditions. Achieving a balance between activity and stability is essential for ensuring sustained and reliable catalytic performance. Various strategies and methodologies have been proposed by researchers aiming to address this challenge. For example, to mitigate cobalt dissolution under acidic conditions, alloying Co with inert or noble elements such as Ru, Ir, Ti, Cr, or W has been shown to effectively form stable intermetallic compounds or high entropy materials (HEM). These modifications not only improve corrosion resistance but also regulate the electronic structure—particularly by modulating the d-band center—to optimize the adsorption energies of reaction intermediates [59–61]. Furthermore, anion doping with elements such as P, N, S, Se, or F can introduce strong covalent interactions within the catalyst lattice, thereby stabilizing the electronic configuration and enhancing structural robustness [62–65]. Constructing metastable [66,67] or passivating structures—such as amorphous phases [68] or applying protective coatings—can effectively shield active sites from acidic corrosion while preserving efficient charge transport. On the other hand, enhancing the intrinsic activity can effectively reduce the required overpotential, thereby mitigating catalyst degradation. This enhancement can be achieved through strategies such as defect site engineering, introduction of oxygen vacancies (Ov) [69,70], construction of heterojunctions to modulate charge distribution, or incorporation of atomically dispersed Co-N-C sites with high catalytic efficiency [71–73], all of which have been shown to significantly improve both catalytic activity and stability. Given these developments, it is both necessary and timely to provide a comprehensive review that summarizes the strategies for enhancing both the activity and stability of Co-based nanomaterials, with the aim of extending these approaches to other transition metal catalysts. Unlike the extensive focus on various acidic catalysts, particularly those based on noble metals, found in other review articles, this review offers a comprehensive and focused compilation of the latest research on the activity and stability of non-noble Co-based nanomaterials. The aim is to establish a rigorous scientific framework for understanding the fundamental principles that govern the activity and stability of transition metal-based catalysts for acidic OER in PEMWEs. The review outlines key strategies for enhancing both activity and stability, categorized into three main types, as illustrated in Fig. 2 : (i) increasing anti-corrosion ability and expanding the active area of catalysts by incorporating corrosion-resistant metals (e.g., Ru, Ir, Mn, Mo) or dispersing catalysts onto acid-resistant supports; (ii) enhancing intrinsic structural stability and active site efficiency by geometry optimization through constructing heterojunctions to stabilize Co sites or leveraging the high entropy effect to reduce diffusion and stabilize the catalyst; (iii) optimizing reaction mechanisms and pathways to stabilize the catalyst while enhancing the efficiency of active sites. Finally, the review addresses the challenges and prospects of transition metal-based catalysts for acidic OER, offering insights into potential avenues for further research and development of PEMWEs. 2 Strategies to enhance activity and stability 2.1 Increasing the corrosion resistance and active surface area Increasing the corrosion resistance and active surface area of catalysts is crucial for enhancing their performance in acidic OER. This can be achieved through two main strategies: (1) incorporating precious metals or other corrosion-resistant metals to form alloys and (2) dispersing the catalyst on acid-resistant supports or encapsulating it within acid-resistant materials. This last approach not only improves the stability of the catalyst by protecting it from harsh acidic environments but also enhances its activity by increasing the accessibility of active sites. 2.1.1 Incorporation of corrosion-resistant metals Noble metals possessing 4d and 5d orbitals feature extensive d-electronic wave-function spatial extents, which can create varied electronic structures when alloyed with 3d metals. This integration significantly modulates the activity at the 3d metal sites. Thereby, by incorporating low-content noble metals into Co-based compounds, it is possible to develop prospective OER electrocatalysts that not only exhibit optimized catalytic performance but also maintain robust stability. For example, Li et al. proved that Sr2CoIrO6− δ exhibited good OER performance associated with the synergy between Co and Ir sites [74]. Pi et al. demonstrated IrCo bimetallic nanoclusters showing good OER activity [75]. The atomic dispersion of Ir on Co3O4 nanosheets (Ir-Co3O4), accompanied by a strong electronic interaction, resulted in enhanced conductivity and reduced reaction energy barriers, thereby improving both the overall OER activity and stability. Ir-Co3O4 nanosheets with a thickness of 3 nm were synthesized using a simple and cost-effective mechanochemical method [76]. Ir single atom was uniformly dispersed on the surface of Co3O4 (Fig. 3 a, b), with the interaction characterized by Ir–O and Ir–Co bonds (Fig. 3c). The loading content significantly influenced the modulation of the coordination environment of both Co and Ir, thereby affecting the adsorption and desorption of intermediates during the OER process. Ir-Co3O4 with an Ir content of 1.05 at% exhibited the best OER activity in an acidic medium, achieving a low overpotential of 236 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and a small Tafel slope of 52.6 mV dec−1 (Fig. 3d). Both high-valence Ir and Co atoms, together with their bridging electrophilic oxygen ligands, served as active sites that jointly facilitated charge transfer during electrochemical reactions. The mass activity and turnover frequency (TOF) of Ir-Co3O4 were superior to those of commercial IrO2. Additionally, Ir-Co3O4 demonstrated enhanced stability, maintaining activity for 30 h (Fig. 3e), significantly outperforming IrO2 and Co3O4, which exhibited only 6–12 h of stability. The catalysts underwent a leaching process, which occurred preferentially at the Co sites. By incorporating Ir single atoms in host Co3O4 nanosheets, the dissolution of Co sites in Ir-Co3O4 was mitigated, contributing to improved stability (Fig. 3f). Operando X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) revealed the partial oxidation of Ir atoms, which promoted the O–O bond formation. Additionally, Ir-Co3O4 exhibited more vacant d orbitals than IrO2, enhancing its ability to hybridize with the O 2p orbitals, thereby promoting d-p orbital coupling and improving catalytic activity. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations further elucidated that the electrophilic state of the oxygen ligands, induced by the high valence of Ir, enhanced electronic conductivity. The interaction between Ir and Co improved the activity of Co sites and lowered the OER energy barrier (Fig. 3g). An additional example was provided by Yin et al., who synthesized Ir single-atom catalysts (Ir-SACs) integrated with Ov on NiCo2O4 nanosheets (Ir-NiCo2O4 NSs) (Fig. 3h) using a co-electrodeposition method [31]. Ir in Ir-NiCo2O4 exhibited an Ir–O scattering path at the first shell, while the second Ir–Ir shell and the third Ir–Ir shell were not observed in the materials, indicating successfully prepared Ir single-atom catalysts (Fig. 3i, j). Ir-NiCo2O4 NSs demonstrated exceptional OER activity in acid media with a low overpotential of 240 mV at 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 3k), and exhibited stability of 70 h (Fig. 3l). After prolonged OER operation, the Ir-NiCo2O4 NSs maintained their structural integrity and chemical composition, with Ir-O x emerging on the surface and only slight leaching of Ni/Co, accompanied by an increase in O content. Incorporated surface atomic Ir, anchored near Co sites and Ov, significantly enhanced electron exchange and transfer efficiency, thereby improving overall catalytic activity. Moreover, the synergistic interaction between Ir and the under-coordinated Ni/Co sites not only facilitated initial H2O adsorption and activation but also stabilized the Co valence state, effectively mitigating overoxidation issues commonly observed in conventional NiCo2O4 systems. The role of Ni in the catalyst was primarily to stabilize the local electron-transfer environment near the Co sites. Although a certain amount of noble metal was introduced, both the noble metal and Co atoms serve as essential active sites during the catalytic process. Through synergistic regulation of the electronic structure, promotion of intermediate adsorption and conversion, and stabilization of metal valence states, they jointly enhance both the activity and durability of the catalyst. This cooperative enhancement not only maximizes the catalytic efficiency of noble metals but also optimizes the performance of transition metal centers, offering an effective strategy for designing high-performance and resource-efficient catalytic systems. The inclusion of other elements beyond noble metals has also been shown to effectively enhance the stability of Co-based catalysts under acidic conditions, while still maintaining high catalytic activity. For instance, while Co3O4 exhibits poor stability in acidic environments and suffers from severe corrosion even at a low current density of 0.1 mA cm−2 [77], composite oxides, such as CoPbO x , CoFePbO x , and CoFeO x , have been proven enhanced stability [23,78–80]. Manganese dioxide (MnO2) is known for its high stability in acidic media. Notably, γ-MnO2 can remain stable for over 8000 h at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 at pH = 2 [3]. Therefore, the formation of binary oxides like Co2MnO4 presents a promising approach as a potential OER catalyst, offering both high activity and enhanced stability in acidic conditions. As an example, two-dimensional (2D) Co2MnO4 nanosheets were synthesized directly on the fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) substrate by a thermal decomposition method, which displayed an ultrathin structure, where Mn3+ and/or Mn4+ along with Co3+ occupies the octahedral sites, while Co2+ is positioned in the tetrahedral sites (Fig. 4 a–c) [23], which exhibited exceptional catalytic activity, surpassing a current density of 1000 mA cm−2, well above that of other 3d transition metal catalysts (Fig. 4d). Additionally, the Co2MnO4 nanosheets demonstrated robust performance for over 1500 h at 200 mA cm−2 with no observable changes in metal bond lengths, indicating stable structural integrity (Fig. 4e). The stability of Co2MnO4 was influenced by both leaching and physical detachment. At high current densities (>1000 mA cm−2-geo), intense bubble formation caused mechanical detachment, with over 90% of Co lost as a solid precipitate. In contrast, at lower current densities (100 mA cm−2-geo), Co loss occurred mainly through dissolution. Notably, Co2MnO4 showed better mass stability than many 3d metal catalysts, though increasing catalyst loading yields diminishing returns on lifetime. DFT calculations revealed that Co3O4 and Co2MnO4 had higher catalytic activity compared to CoMn2O4 and MnO2 (Fig. 4f). The doping of Mn into Co2MnO4 suppressed the metal dissolution process. Moreover, the oxygen lattice (OL) in Co2MnO4 was significantly more thermodynamically stable, which enhanced the overall stability of the catalyst. The strong hybridization between Co 3d orbitals and O 2p orbitals in Co2MnO4 resulted in higher O* adsorption energy, thus improving the catalytic activity (Fig. 4g). Similarly, spinel cobalt oxide fibers doped with La and Mn ions (LMCF) and synthesized via an electrospinning and annealing process (Fig. 4h) [81] exhibited great OER activity, achieving an overpotential of 353 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in 0.1 M HClO4 and displaying minimal degradation over a 360 h OER operation (Fig. 4i). Potentiostatic measurement of PEMWE with LMCF anodic catalyst at the cell potential of 1.65 V was conducted for over 100 h and it facilitated a remarkable current density at 2 A cm−2 with negligible degradation. In situ XAS analysis of LMCF during the OER process revealed notable structural changes, including a shortened Co–O bond length and increased covalency, which contributed to the enhanced activity and stability (Fig. 4j and k). The Pourbaix diagram indicated the stability of LMCF across various pH conditions, identifying a stable La3O-CoTO* phase crucial for PEMWE performance in the pH range of 0–4, particularly at higher potentials of 2–3 V (Fig. 4l). DFT calculations demonstrated that Mn and La ions preferentially substituted Co in octahedral sites, enhancing electrical conductivity and promoting the formation of beneficial Ov. The incorporation of La and Mn improved electron mobility, leading to high OER activity and confirming LMCF as a promising and durable catalyst for green hydrogen production in acidic media. 2.1.2 Dispersion and encapsulation of catalysts on acid-resistant materials The dispersion and/or encapsulation of catalysts on acid-resistant materials has emerged as a promising strategy to prevent the leaching of transition metal catalysts during the OER process. Acid-resistant support materials effectively limit the direct interaction between the catalyst and protons (H+) in acidic electrolytes, thereby significantly reducing the dissolution of metal ions. This approach enhances the long-term stability of the catalysts, offering a viable solution to degradation in acidic environments. N-doped carbon (CN) can effectively protect Co ions from corrosion in acidic electrolytes, thereby preventing their deactivation. For instance, Co3O4 hollow nanocubes supported on CN coated on FTO glass (Co3O4@NAC/FTO) by electrodeposition followed by post-annealing showed remarkable electrocatalytic performance with an overpotential of 465 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in 0.5 M H2SO4. The catalyst maintained stability for 12 h with only a 10% increase in applied potential [82]. Similarly, Zhang et al. developed defect-rich N-doped Co3O4 nanoparticles on CN (N-Co3O4@NC) for OER, through annealing of ZIF-67 under the NH3 atmosphere, where the CN acted as a protective layer for Co3O4. Chronoamperometric measurement of N-Co3O4@NC at a constant potential of 1.51 V (vs. reversible hydrogen electrode, RHE) showed that the electrocatalyst sustained its current density for more than 30 h [83]. DFT calculations further revealed that CN enhanced the conductivity of the catalyst and accelerated reaction kinetics, thereby improving the overall OER activity. Co3O4/CN with abundant Ov was synthesized through a simple carbonization-oxidation process [64] (Fig. 5 a, b), which exhibited outstanding OER performance with a low overpotential of 225 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in 0.5 M H2SO4 and maintained stability for 80 h due to its robust 3D/2D hierarchical structure (Fig. 5c). The hierarchical 3D/2D configuration provided numerous exposed edge sites, which served as active sites to enhance the catalytic activity. Furthermore, the surface CN shell acted as a protective layer, preventing the deactivation of Co3O4 and facilitating electron and mass transfer, thereby accelerating the OER kinetics in acidic conditions. After 3000 cyclic voltammetry (CV) cycles, the morphology and composition of the catalyst remained largely unchanged, with only a slight decrease in O and N contents, indicating minimal degradation. In situ attenuated total reflectance Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (ATR-FTIR) detected the key intermediate species O*O, providing direct evidence for the lattice oxygen mechanism (LOM) at the active Ov sites, which reduced the adsorption free energy of oxygen intermediates (Fig. 5d). Co3O4 and Co3S4 supported on reduced graphene oxide (Co3O4@rGO, Co3S4@rGO) were prepared through a hydrothermal method and used as bifunctional catalysts for anode and cathode in PEMWE (Fig. 5e) [84]. XAS analysis revealed the formation of Co–O and Co–S bonds at the interfaces between Co3O4/Co3S4 and rGO, which effectively modified the electronic structure of the Co ions (Fig. 5f and g). The Co3S4@rGO catalyst demonstrated superior performance for both HER and OER with overpotentials of 151 and 350 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in 0.5 M H2SO4, respectively, while maintaining good stability for over 8 h (Fig. 5h). When employed as both cathode and anode catalysts in a two-electrode electrolyzer configuration, the Co3S4@rGO-based device achieved a cell voltage of 1.82 V to drive a current density of 10 mA cm−2, exhibiting excellent durability in acidic media (Fig. 5i). The stability tests revealed significant leaching of Co, O, and S from both Co3O4@rGO nanobox and Co3S4@rGO nanosheet catalysts in strong acidic media, leading to structural distortion and decreased stability of the electrocatalysts. Beyond merely supporting them, encapsulating active materials within acid-resistant matrices can further enhance their stability by shielding the active sites from harsh acidic conditions. This protective encapsulation significantly reduces the risk of corrosion and bolsters the long-term durability of the catalysts during electrochemical reactions. The key challenge, however, lies in maintaining the activity of these encapsulated sites, ensuring that they remain catalytically active and effective in driving the desired reactions. This balance between protection and functional accessibility is crucial for optimizing the performance of encapsulated catalysts. For instance, Wang et al. reported IrCo@carbon nanotubes (CNT)/carbon cloth (CC) catalysts showing excellent HER and OER performance [85]. The synthesis route is shown in Fig. 6 (a). A piece of acid-treated CC was vertically immersed into the solution of 2-methylimidazole (2-MeIM) and Co(NO3)2 to grow the ZIF-L-Co nanosheets by a self-assembly process. Subsequently, it was immersed in a low concentration of Ir3+ aqueous solution to form Ir-etch-ZIF-L-Co/CC by a cation exchange process. Ir-etch-ZIF-L-Co/CC maintained the same morphology and crystal structure as ZIF-L-Co/CC with slight etching traces at the edges (Fig. 6b). Finally, IrCo@CNT/CC was prepared by placing dicyandiamide (DCDA) at the upstream position of Ir-etch-ZIF-L-Co/CC in a tubular furnace during the annealing process. The Co@CNT/CC control sample was also synthesized using the same method without introducing Ir ions. Raman spectra indicated that Co@CNT/CC exhibited a lower defect density than IrCo@CNT/CC (Fig. 6c). The IrCo@CNT/CC catalyst demonstrated exceptional durability for OER in acidic electrolytes (Fig. 6d) with negligible overpotential increase after 90 h of continuous testing at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 6e). This durability significantly surpasses that of other catalysts, which typically maintain stability for only 5–15 h, highlighting the robustness and effectiveness of the IrCo@CNT/CC configuration in prolonged operational conditions. The IrCo@CNT/CC catalyst maintained its overall morphology during OER, but significant Co dissolution occurred, leading to the formation of Co-doped IrO2 on the nanoparticle surface. While the incorporation of carbon materials in catalyst systems can effectively mitigate metal dissolution and oxidation in acidic environments, thereby enhancing the long-term stability of the catalyst, it is crucial to recognize that carbon materials themselves are susceptible to oxidation under acidic conditions. In acidic electrolytes, carbon undergoes rapid oxidation, resulting in the formation of oxygenated functional groups such as carboxyl, lactone, and ester groups [86]. Protons readily react with defect-rich carbon surfaces to form soluble species, and strong acids such as H2SO4 can act as direct oxidants, accelerating carbon corrosion. These oxidative transformations introduce additional surface defects and may disrupt the synergy between carbon supports and metal active sites, ultimately compromising catalytic stability and performance. For example, Zhao et al. [87] revealed that Fe-N-C catalysts undergo significant degradation in acidic media, attributing the loss of ∼75% of active sites to combined Fe demetalation and carbon corrosion. This degradation was further linked to impaired proton and electron transport across the catalyst layer, with a fourfold decrease in proton transport kinetics observed during stability testing. Despite the widespread use of carbon materials as conductive supports in PEMWEs, their susceptibility to electrochemical oxidation under acidic and anodic OER conditions—especially at potentials above 1.5 V vs. RHE-remains underappreciated. Yet, many studies focus on catalyst activity or metal site stability, often overlooking the long-term deterioration of the carbon support. Therefore, greater attention should be directed toward understanding and mitigating carbon corrosion in acidic OER environments to ensure the durability of the catalyst layer. An amorphous Mo-Ce oxide supported single-atom Co (CoSA-MoCeO x ) encapsulated in bamboo-like carbon nanotubes (CoSA-MoCeO x @BCT) was synthesized and tested as an OER electrocatalyst (Fig. 6f) [88]. As demonstrated in Fig. 6(g), CoSA-MoCeO x @BCT exhibited a significantly low OER overpotential of 239 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2, compared to BCT (612 mV), MoCeO x (470 mV), and CoSA-MoCeO x (333 mV). Additionally, the Faradaic efficiency (FE) of CoSA-MoCeO x @BCT was 98.9%, substantially higher than that of MoCeO x (58.3%) and CoSA-MoCeO x (91.0%) (Fig. 6h). This demonstrates that Co sites effectively mitigated undesired side reactions during the OER in these materials. Moreover, the dual-metal-site LOM pathway in CoSA-MoCeO x further enhanced the OER activity (Fig. 6i). Due to the strong interaction between the single-atom Co sites and Mo-Ce oxide, coupled with the pronounced confinement effect of the BCT, which reduced direct contact between the catalyst and the acidic electrolyte, the catalyst exhibited enhanced corrosion resistance. Therefore, the optimized catalyst demonstrated outstanding stability for over 60 h in PEMWEs. The introduction of CoSA active sites and the confinement effect of BCT significantly enhanced the catalyst corrosion resistance, reducing the dissolution of Mo and Co atoms in acidic media. Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) analysis further confirmed the reduced leaching of Mo and Co, with CoSA-MoCeO x @BCT showing nearly 303 times more residual Co compared to CoSA-MoCeO x . While most catalysts require good hydrophilicity to ensure sufficient contact with the electrolyte for efficient electrochemical reactions, in certain cases, using hydrophobic materials as protective layers can reduce catalyst corrosion and thereby enhance stability. Hydrophobic materials can effectively isolate the catalyst from excessive water or corrosive ions, such as H+ in the acidic environment, slowing down the dissolution of metal ions and contributing to the long-term stability of the catalyst. For example, Co3O4@C composites, where Co3O4 nanoparticles were loaded onto the carbon surface and subsequently mixed with graphite and paraffin oil (GPO) in a desired ratio (denoted as x-Co3O4@C/GPO, with x representing the Co3O4@C content) [89]. Due to the synergistic interaction between Co3O4 nanoparticles and the carbon-based protecting matrix, Co3O4@C/GPO effectively avoided Co dissolution and improved the stability of the catalyst. 40-Co3O4@C/GPO composites required only 360 mV to drive the current density of 10 mA cm−2 and could be stable for over 43 h with a potential increase of just 27 mV and a FE of 96%. The hydrophobic GPO binder was shown to significantly enhance the acidic stability of the Co3O4@C component, by comparison with Co3O4@C catalysts deposited on the glassy carbon electrode with Nafion binder, which exhibited rapid deactivation within 30 min. 2.2 Enhancing the intrinsic structural stability and active site efficiency In addition to enhancing corrosion resistance and increasing the active surface area, as discussed in Section 2.1, recent efforts have aimed at improving the intrinsic activity and stability of catalysts by geometry optimization through introducing heterojunctions or through alloying with multiple elements, potentially within the framework of HEMs. Heterostructured materials significantly improve catalytic performance by optimizing charge distribution and electron transfer properties, thereby lowering reaction energy barriers [42,90]. Moreover, the tailored interfaces in heterojunctions can minimize undesirable side reactions and bolster the stability of the catalyst under harsh reaction conditions. On the other hand, HEMs, typically comprising five or more elements in near-equimolar ratios, possess unique properties advantageous for catalysis [91–93]. The atomic disorder within HEMs promotes enhanced catalytic activity by generating abundant defects, improving charge distribution, modifying the electronic structure, and stabilizing reactive sites. These materials also display superior stability compared to binary and ternary catalysts, thanks to the solid solution-induced sluggish diffusion effect, which provides increased resistance to leaching. The heightened thermodynamic stability of HEMs further underscores their capability to perform under extreme conditions. 2.2.1 Geometry optimization Carbon-coated Co3O4 array on carbon fiber paper (Co3O4@C/CP) was developed by electroplating methods combined with two-step calcined treatments, which were engineered with a vertically aligned geometry to optimize active site exposure and facilitated rapid mass and charge transport. This structural design allowed the catalyst to achieve a low overpotential of approximately 370 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in 0.5 M H2SO4, demonstrating superior OER activity compared to many transition metal oxide counterparts. Furthermore, the catalyst maintained a stable current density over 80 h of continuous operation at 100 mA cm−2 with negligible degradation, highlighting its remarkable acid durability. The nanoarray configuration enabled efficient electrolyte penetration and minimized diffusion resistance, while the conformal carbon layer enhanced electronic conductivity and acted as a robust barrier against acid corrosion [53]. Heterojunctions significantly enhance the catalytic activity and stability of materials by modulating charge interactions and optimizing structural stability at the interface. When two materials with distinct work functions are combined to form a heterojunction, electrons transfer from the material with a lower work function to the one with a higher work function [94,95]. This electron migration generates an internal electric field and establishes a space charge region at the interface. The internal electric field can effectively drive charge carriers (electrons and holes) toward catalytically active sites, thereby minimizing recombination losses and enhancing charge transfer kinetics during catalytic reactions [96]. The presence of the space charge region leads to the equilibration of Fermi levels between the two materials. This realignment modulates the electronic density of states near the Fermi level, altering the bonding and anti-bonding characteristics of the active sites [97]. Consequently, the adsorption and desorption energy barriers for reaction intermediates, such as *O, *OH, and *OOH species in the OER, are modified. Beyond electronic enhancements, the heterojunction interface contributes to structural stability by introducing lattice strain/distortion [16], stabilizing the metal valence state [98], and inhibiting the migration of metal ions [99]. Therefore, the synergistic effects within heterojunctions not only amplify intrinsic catalytic activity through efficient charge separation and optimized intermediate binding but they can also significantly enhance the stability of catalysts in long-term electrochemical applications. Based on the unique advantages of heterostructures in enhancing catalytic performance, Huang et al. synthesized a Co3O4/CeO2 nanocomposite via electrodeposition followed by annealing in air (Fig. 7 a) [25]. The Co3O4/CeO2 heterojunction exhibited notable OER performance, with an overpotential of 423 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and a Tafel slope of 88.1 mV dec−1 in 0.5 M H2SO4 (Fig. 7b and c). Furthermore, the catalyst showed robust stability and maintained its activity for over 50 h with minimal elemental dissolution. CV curves (Fig. 7d) revealed that the formation of the heterojunction modified the redox properties and local electronic environment of Co3O4, facilitating the oxidation of Co to higher-valence Co(III) and Co(IV) species. Additionally, electrochemical surface area (ECSA)-normalized CV curves (Fig. 7e) and higher surface activation energy (E a) (Fig. 7f) indicated that Co3O4/CeO2 possessed higher intrinsic activity compared to pure Co3O4, further validating the beneficial impact of the heterojunction structure in improving the overall electrocatalytic performance. Moreover, Co3O4/CeO2 demonstrated significantly reduced metal dissolution compared to pure Co3O4, highlighting its enhanced durability and potential for practical applications in PEMWEs. Ex situ XAS and in situ Raman spectroscopy analyses (Fig. 7g–i) revealed that the Co ions in the Co3O4 component of the heterojunction were more readily oxidized to the highly active Co(IV) species, consistent with the CV analysis. This enhancement was attributed to the heterojunction-induced modification of the electronic structure and the adjustment of the local coordination environment. The presence of CeO2 effectively suppressed charge accumulation on Co3O4 in the heterojunction structure, ultimately improving both the catalytic activity and stability of the composite under OER conditions. Building on the concept of heterojunction catalysts for enhancing OER performance, a Zr-Co9S8/Co3O4 heterojunction was designed and synthesized by the solvothermal method to modulate adsorption/desorption properties and improve both activity and stability in water oxidation reactions [100]. The electronic interactions at the heterojunction interface facilitated charge redistribution, as confirmed by charge density difference distribution (Fig. 8 a), thus enhancing electron mobility and significantly reducing energy barriers by modulating the adsorption and desorption ability of oxygen-containing intermediates. The d band center of Zr-Co9S8/Co3O4 heterojunction catalysts with Co-Co dinuclear active sites (denoted as Co-Co DASs/ZCC) was calculated at −3.47 eV, notably lower than that of the Zr-Co9S8 at −2.52 eV (Fig. 8b). This shift indicated a weakened interaction between the adsorbate and the catalyst surface, decreasing the anti-bonding state and thus reducing the adsorption strength of intermediates (Fig. 8c). Structural analysis revealed slightly elongated Co–O bonds (1.95 Å) within Co-Co DASs/ZCC due to the formation of S–Co–O bonds at the heterojunction interface, compared to 1.91 Å in bulk Co3O4 (Fig. 8d). This unique electronic and structural configuration resulted in superior OER performance, as evidenced by the lower overpotential and Tafel slope of Co-Co DASs/ZCC compared to control samples, highlighting its favorable reaction kinetics (Fig. 8e, f). Additionally, Co-Co DASs/ZCC demonstrated excellent durability, maintaining stable operation for 40 h with a negligible potential increase under constant current conditions. When employed as the anode catalyst in a two-electrode water electrolyzer paired with Pt/C as the cathode, the system exhibited remarkable long-term stability at a high current density of 100 mA cm−2 for 500 h (Fig. 8g), surpassing reported Mn-based and Ru-based catalysts, thus positioning it as an attractive non-precious metal acidic OER catalyst with superior performance for PEMWEs. The enhanced stability of Co-Co DASs/ZCC was attributed to the heterojunction-induced elongation of Co–O bonds, which provides increased resistance to dissolution under acidic conditions. As another example of a successful heterostructured catalyst, Co3O4/MnO2, which was synthesized by ball milling, exhibited exceptional OER performance, significantly improving both activity and stability over pure phase Co3O4 (Fig. 8h–j). As anodic catalysts in PEMWEs, Co3O4/MnO2 achieved superior performance, with a cell voltage at 1 A cm−2 that was 56 mV lower than RuO2, and showed minimal degradation at current densities exceeding 250 mA cm−2 for 1000 s [101]. Additionally, the heterostructure effectively slowed down surface reconstruction by reducing the number of tetrahedral Co sites, which were easily oxidized, stabilizing the Mn valence, thus mitigating the Co and Mn leaching. The minimized Co and Mn leaching contributed to the long-term durability. These results emphasize the potential of heterostructured catalysts to promote OER performance and provide a promising pathway for the development of stable and efficient electrocatalysts in energy conversion technologies, particularly PEMWEs. In an effort to address the challenges of catalyst dissolution and instability in acidic OER, Liu et al. designed a RuCo/RuCoO x core/shell heterojunction with an ultrathin and conformal depletion layer, which formed a built-in Schottky barrier at the interface [71]. The core-shell structure was fabricated by a controlled oxidation approach by regulating the oxidation conditions of RuCo alloy nanospheres at different temperatures. This unique heterostructure facilitated directional charge redistribution, driving electron transfer from RuCo alloy to RuCoO x , thus optimizing the electronic structure of the surface-active Ru sites. The resultant electron-deficient environment effectively suppressed the overoxidation and subsequent dissolution of Ru during anodic operation. In a standard three-electrode system with 0.5 M H2SO4 electrolyte, the catalyst achieved an overpotential of only ∼170 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and demonstrated exceptional operational durability for over 2500 h. Furthermore, when applied as the anode in a PEMWE, the system required just 1.78 V to reach a high current density of 1 A cm−2 and sustained stable operation for more than 200 h at 200 mA cm−2. After 200 h of OER operation, the catalyst retained its initial RuCo/RuCoO x core-shell heterostructure with only a slight thickening of the oxide shell (∼2 nm). Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) analysis further revealed that the dissolution of Ru and Co predominantly occurred in the initial 10 h, after which the concentrations stabilized at relatively low levels (0.37 ppm for Ru and 0.26 ppm for Co after 100 h). This controlled dissolution behavior could be attributed to the formation of a conformal and ultrathin oxide shell, which acted as a closed Schottky junction with a depletion layer, effectively mitigating corrosion and preventing the leaching of the underlying RuCo alloy core. The RuO2/CoMnO3 nanosheet catalyst, synthesized via a straightforward solid-phase pyrolysis method, demonstrated a promising strategy for reducing Ru loading while maintaining excellent acidic OER performance [102]. The vertically aligned ultrathin nanosheet architecture provided a high surface-to-volume ratio, facilitating the exposure of active sites and promoting rapid ion diffusion. The intimate interfacial contact between RuO2 nanoparticles and the CoMnO3 matrix enabled efficient charge transfer across the heterojunction, while simultaneously tuning the local coordination environment of Ru active centers via the bridging oxygen atoms. The catalyst exhibited a high mass activity of 1742.9 A gRu −1 at 1.53 V and maintained stability over 500 h at 10 mA cm−2. The robust nanosheet framework and stable heterointerface suppressed Ru dissolution and preserved catalytic integrity under harsh acidic conditions. The well-defined RuO2/CoMnO3 heterointerface suppressed LOM and enhanced the activity through the AEM. 2.2.2 Developing high-entropy materials HEMs demonstrate unique electronic and thermodynamic stability due to the high configurational entropy created by the extensive mixing of diverse elements within their crystal lattice, resulting in a single solid solution [103]. This extensive elemental diversity also leads to a quasi-continuous distribution of surface energy levels, arising from the numerous different chemical and electronic environments produced by combining such a large number of elements. The high entropy effect enhances synergistic interactions among different elements, modulating the electronic structure of the metals and boosting their intrinsic activity. The incorporation of multiple elements with varying electronegativities and atomic sizes within the alloy lattice creates a complex and heterogeneous environment, fostering diverse local coordination environments around metal active sites. Additionally, the inherently sluggish diffusion processes in HEMs help stabilize the active sites by suppressing undesirable surface reconstruction and dissolution, thus enhancing their long-term stability [104,105]. They also show structure stabilization properties, inhibiting the phase transitions during the complex redox reactions because of cocktail effects and lattice distortions. These characteristics render HEMs as highly active and stable catalysts [106,107]. Recent research has leveraged the promising properties of high entropy alloys (HEAs) for acidic OER applications, capitalizing on their exceptional catalytic activity and stability over extended periods. For example, ZnNiCoIrMn HEA nanospheres, with a size of 200 nm, were synthesized using a sol-gel and dealloying method in a vacuum system, with Zn acting as the sacrificial element (Fig. 9 a) [108]. The resulting ZnNiCoIrMn HEA exhibited a nanoporous structure and high crystallinity (Fig. 9b). Despite the relatively low Ir content, this HEA demonstrated remarkable performance, achieving an overpotential of 237 mV for the acidic OER at 10 mA cm−2 and a Tafel slope of 46 mV dec−1. During the activation process, the ZnNiCoIrMn HEA underwent surface reconstruction, resulting in complete Zn leaching, an Ir-enriched surface, and the oxidation of other metal elements to form an oxyhydroxide surface. DFT calculations revealed that the increased number of d-band holes in Ir enhanced the electrophilic nature of oxygen intermediates, facilitating the nucleophilic attack of water molecules and thereby lowering the kinetic barrier for the OER (Fig. 9c). The modulation of the electron state of Ir effectively influenced the adsorption and desorption processes of OER intermediates, thereby enhancing catalytic activity. Furthermore, the high entropy, coupled with the sluggish ion diffusion effect, contributed to the long-term stability of the ZnNiCoIrMn HEA, which maintained its activity over 100 h. This excellent stability was attributed to the incorporation of Mn, which suppressed dissolution by enhancing cohesive energy and reducing the adsorption energy of oxygen species at Ir sites. In addition to HEAs, other HEMs, including chalcogenides and oxides, have also been explored as efficient and stable catalysts for acidic OER. For example, Jo et al. developed CoFeNiMoWTe high entropy chalcogenide glasses as efficient acidic OER catalysts through a combination of electrochemical deposition and posterior tellurization processes (Fig. 9d) [60]. CoFeNiMoWTe catalysts displayed a single face-centered cubic (FCC) phase (Fig. 9e) and demonstrated exceptional OER performance in acidic conditions, with an overpotential of 373 mV and outstanding stability over 100 h at 10 mA cm−2 in 0.5 M H2SO4 (Fig. 9f–h). Due to the high entropy effect, CoFeNiMoWTe demonstrated superior electrochemical stability compared to other alloys and tellurides (Fig. 9i). H-type two-electrode water electrolysis cell was further evaluated by using CoFeNiMoWTe as the anode and Pt/C as the cathode. As shown in Fig. 9(j), the two-electrode cell showed excellent performance with a cell voltage of 1.63 V at 10 mA cm−2, which was lower than that of the CoFeNiMoW-based cell (1.72 V). When used as an anode catalyst in a PEMWE device, CoFeNiMoWTe achieved a low cell voltage of 1.81 V at 70 °C at 1 A cm−2, with remarkable long-term stability over 100 h (Fig. 9k). The incorporation of Te promoted the formation of an amorphous structure and provided abundant terminal atoms, leading to higher valence states for Co, Fe, Mo, Ni, and W at 2.48, 2.51, 4.86, 2.44, and 4.44, respectively. After the OER reaction, the 3d transition metals exhibited negligible increases in their average valence states, indicating that the high entropy effect effectively prevented surface oxidation and reconstruction for these metals. In contrast, the valence of Mo and W increased, suggesting that these elements were oxidized to form metal hydroxide or oxide passivation layers, which suppressed corrosion for other metals and enhanced the stability of the CoFeNiMoWTe catalyst. High entropy oxides (HEOs) have also garnered extensive attention in OER research. For example, Hu et al. synthesized M-RuIrFeCoNiO2 HEOs using a rapid, nonequilibrium cooling strategy, where molten sodium nitrate was mixed homogeneously with various metal chlorides and rapidly quenched (Fig. 10 a) [109]. M-RuIrFeCoNiO2 exhibited a single-phase rutile RuO2 structure (Fig. 10b), but with significantly increased structural disorder compared to conventional crystalline RuO2, as evidenced by the absence of distant coordination shell configurations (Fig. 10c). The M-RuIrFeCoNiO2 HEOs demonstrated excellent OER activity, achieving a low overpotential of 189 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 and a Tafel slope of 49 mV dec−1, indicative of fast charge transfer and OER kinetics (Fig. 10d). Further insights from operando Raman spectroscopy revealed the formation of stable active Ru/IrO x ∙ xH2O species during the anodic OER process. Additionally, methanol oxidation experiments suggested that M-RuIrFeCoNiO2 exhibited a stronger tendency to adsorb OH* intermediates, which contributed to its superior OER performance. To elucidate the OER mechanism, operando isotope-labelled differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS) was conducted on M-RuIrFeCoNiO2 and M-RuO2 using H2 18O and H2 16O in aqueous H2SO4 electrolytes (Fig. 10e–g). The DEMS results indicated that the incorporation of Ir effectively suppressed lattice oxygen participation in the OER process. The synthesized M-RuIrFeCoNiO2 was subsequently employed as the anode catalyst in a PEMWE operating at 80 °C, with commercial Pt/C as the cathode catalyst. At a high current density of 1 A cm−2, the cell voltage exhibited remarkable stability, with minimal degradation over 500 h of continuous electrolysis (Fig. 10h). M-RuIrFeCoNiO2 demonstrated notable resistance to metal dissolution and phase segregation under acidic OER conditions. A rapid leaching of Fe, Co, and Ni occurred within the first 2 h, followed by a substantial decrease in dissolution rate, while Ru and Ir exhibited minimal loss, with 84 wt% and 90 wt% retention after 10 h, respectively. Post-stability characterization confirmed the preservation of the RuO2 phase and a uniform elemental distribution, despite a slight decrease in the intensities of Fe, Co, and Ni. Ir retained its +4 oxidation state, and Ru showed a slight increase in valence, indicating that Ir incorporation enhanced structural stability and suppressed metal loss during prolonged operation. Combining HEMs with heterojunction structures leverages both material and structural advantages, enhancing catalytic activity and stability. IrRuCoNiMo@IrRuNiMoO x nanoparticles (HEA@Ir-MEO) were synthesized using a two-step wet chemical reduction method (Fig. 10i) [110]. Homogeneous IrRuCoNiMo HEA nanoparticles were formed via a fast NaBH4-based reduction process to simultaneously reduce the metal precursors in ethylene glycol. This was followed by the spontaneous galvanic replacement of Ir4+ on the HEA surface, yielding Ir-enriched HEA@Ir-MEO nanoparticles. XRD analysis confirmed the FCC structure of the HEA (Fig. 10j). The HEA@Ir-MEO catalyst exhibited outstanding OER activity, demonstrating low overpotential and high mass activity, positioning it as one of the leading Ir-based electrocatalysts for OER (Fig. 10k). The E a for OER on HEA@Ir-MEO was determined to be 13.50 kJ mol−1, significantly lower than that of IrO2 (18.12 kJ mol−1, Fig. 10l). Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) further supported the enhanced OER kinetics of HEA@Ir-MEO, showing a lower charge transfer resistance (R ct) compared to IrO2 in the membrane electrode assembly (MEA) configuration. The MEA based on HEA@Ir-MEO catalyst exhibited impressive stability at a constant current density of 1.0 A cm−2 at 65 °C, maintaining performance for over 500 h with a voltage degradation rate of approximately 29.06 μV h−1. The HEA@Ir-MEO catalyst demonstrated strong resistance to metal dissolution and phase separation during the OER. The Ir-rich oxide shell protected the internal HEA core from corrosion, as evidenced by low metal leaching in ICP-MS, and stabilized the surface through the formation of Ir/Ru oxides with minimal reconstruction. HRTEM and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping showed no aggregation or elemental segregation, while XAS analysis revealed that multi-metal doping induced lattice distortion, which hindered atomic migration and maintained phase uniformity. These findings confirmed that the high entropy configuration and doped IrO2 shell synergistically suppressed degradation and enabled excellent durability. IrFeCoNiCu nanoparticles supported on carbon paper were synthesized via a microwave-assisted shock synthesis method and evaluated for OER performance in 0.1 M HClO4 electrolyte [111]. The XRD analysis (Fig. 11 a) of IrFeCoNiCu HEA nanoparticles revealed a distinct set of FCC diffraction peaks, indicating a single-phase structure without any secondary phases. Meanwhile, STEM-EDS elemental mapping (Fig. 11b) showed a uniform distribution of all constituent elements. IrFeCoNiCu HEA exhibited superior catalytic activity showing an overpotential of 302 mV at 10 mA cm−2, much lower than that of blank carbon paper (Fig. 11c) and various monometallic and bimetallic counterparts. The HEA catalyst displayed a Tafel slope of 58.0 mV dec−1, significantly lower than that of pure Ir (75.8 mV dec−1), indicating enhanced OER kinetics (Fig. 11d). The HEA catalyst demonstrated excellent stability when operating at a constant current density of 10 mA cm−2 for 12 h, with an overpotential increase of less than 60 mV, in contrast to a 120 mV increase observed for pure Ir, highlighting its improved durability under acidic conditions (Fig. 11e). Further investigation of the structural evolution revealed the formation of an Ir-rich shell layer on the surface of the nanoparticles after 4 h of chronopotentiometry measurement. EDS mapping indicated that while Ir remained uniformly distributed, the 3d transition metals (Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu) showed less content but with an increased diffusivity near the surface (Fig. 11f), which was attributed to that the surface entropy of the HEA was insufficient to fully mitigate the electrochemical redox effects, resulting in a degree of surface reconstruction. Fig. 11(g) illustrates the overall structural transformation, including carbon layer delamination and the dissolution of 3d metal atoms, leading to an Ir-enriched shell while maintaining a homogeneous single-phase HEA core structure. This complex reconstruction and leaching behavior, driven by the multi-element nature of HEAs, is more pronounced compared to simpler monometallic or bimetallic materials, highlighting the need for further research to optimize the composition and control the dissolution dynamics to enhance the stability of these catalysts. The high entropy effect significantly enhances the interactions between the elements on the catalyst surface, improving its resistance to interference during redox reactions and reducing surface reconstruction. This multi-metal approach provides an advantage by stabilizing the catalyst structure, particularly in highly dynamic environments. However, in acidic environments, certain metal elements within the high entropy catalyst may dissolve or migrate, especially 3d transition metals, leading to changes in the surface composition. Thus, while high entropy catalysts show promising potential for acid-catalyzed OER, further optimization of their composition and design is necessary. 2.3 Optimizing the reaction mechanism Understanding and optimizing the reaction mechanism underlying the OER is essential for enhancing its efficiency and performance. Currently, the general mechanisms of acidic OER include the AEM, lattice LOM, and the oxide path mechanism (OPM) [24]. As shown in Fig. 12 (a) and Eqs. (1)–(4), in the AEM, firstly, water molecules undergo oxidation reactions and M-OH is generated on the surface of catalysts. Afterward, M-OH releases an electron and generates an MO intermediate. Subsequently, MO releases an electron while adsorbing another water molecule thus generating MOOH intermediates. Finally, the MOOH intermediate releases an electron to release an oxygen molecule. In AEM, multiple oxygen reaction intermediates are involved and the binding energies of these intermediates are linearly correlated, following the relationship ΔG OOH = ΔG OH + 3.2 ± 0.2 eV [112]. Since the binding energy of each intermediate cannot be independently regulated, a high overpotential is required to drive the OER in the AEM pathway with a theoretical limit calculated to be about 370 ± 100 mV [113]. (1) M + H2O → MOH + H+ + e− (2) MOH → MO + H+ + e− (3) MO + H2O → MOOH + H+ + e− (4) MOOH → M + O2 + H+ + e− In the LOM, OL is involved in the reaction. As shown in Fig. 12(b) and Eqs. (5)–(8), firstly, water molecules undergo oxidation reactions, and M-OH is generated on the surface of catalysts. Afterward, OV acts as the active site to adsorb another water molecule in the electrolyte and release an electron to generate HO-MOH intermediates. Then, HO-MOH undergoes deprotonation, releasing two protons and electrons. Subsequently, MO intermediates combine OL in the catalysts to generate O2 and OV. Finally, OV combines water molecules to generate OL. However, the creation of OV within the LOM pathway can result in metal species detaching from the catalyst surface, causing a decrease in catalyst activity and stability. (5) M + H2O → MOH + H+ + e− (6) OV + MOH + H2O → OH-MOH + H+ + e− (7) OH-MOH → MO + OL + 2H+ + 2e− (8) MO + OL → M + O2 The OPM enables direct O–O radical coupling, thereby overcoming the scaling relationship between oxygen intermediates. The reaction process is illustrated in Fig. 12(c) and summarized in Eqs. (9)–(12). In the first step, similar to the AEM and LOM, a metal site on the catalyst surface adsorbs a water molecule, forming the MOH intermediate. Another metal site then adsorbs a second water molecule, resulting in the formation of HOM-MO intermediates via an electron-releasing process. Following this, the HOM-MO intermediates undergo deprotonation, releasing one proton and one electron to form OM-MO. Finally, the OM-MO intermediates couple directly to release O2. One notable feature of the OPM is that it bypasses the generation of OV and MOOH oxygen intermediates. As a result, the OPM can overcome the scaling relationship between oxygen intermediates, thereby enhancing both stability and catalytic activity. However, unlike the AEM and LOM, the OPM requires more precise geometric configurations of the metal active sites, with suitable bond length distances, to ensure efficient O–O coupling [114,115]. (9) M + H2O → MOH + H+ + e− (10) MOH + H2O → HOM-MO + H+ + e− (11) HOM-MO → OM-MO + H+ + e− (12) OM-MO → M + O2 For instance, Zhou et al. demonstrated that incorporating metal dopants and Ov into Co3O4 could induce a shift from the AEM to the LOM in the OER by DFT calculations [116]. As shown in Fig. 12(d), the rate-determining step (RDS) involved the transition from *O to *OOH, reflecting the challenge in *OOH formation for Co3O4. By co-doping Ru and Mn, Ru surpassed Co in OER activity, with a Gibbs free energy difference of about 1.94 eV between *O and *OOH but Mn exhibited a theoretical overpotential 0.15 V higher than Co via AEM in the co-doped Co3O4 catalysts. Besides, Ov reduced thermodynamic activation energies by 1.19 eV for Mn and 0.64 eV for Ru during the transition from *O to O2 formation, generating new intermediates (*OO, Ov, and Ov + *OH). Thus, at Mn and Ru sites, the energy barriers at RDS in LOM were much lower than that of the AEM (Fig. 12e). Zou et al. demonstrated that regulating reaction pathways was a key strategy for enhancing OER activity [117]. By comparing the OER pathways of Co1.8Ga1.2O4 (a mixed spinel) and Co3O4 (a normal spinel), they investigated AEM and OPM two mechanisms. Energetic analysis revealed distinct pathway preferences between the two catalysts. For Co3O4, the AEM mechanism dominated, with the RDS being the oxidation of *O to *OOH at the CoTd2+ site, presenting a maximum free energy (ΔG max) of 0.44 eV. In contrast, Co1.8Ga1.2O4 exhibited a lower ΔG max (0.34 eV) for the OPM, with the formation of *OH at the CoOh2+-CoOh3+ site identified as the RDS (Fig. 12f), highlighting the critical role of Ga incorporation in enhancing OER activity. The optimized Co1.8Ga1.2O4 catalyst demonstrated exceptional performance, achieving an overpotential of 310 mV at 10 mA cm−2, stable operation at 200 mA cm−2 for 200 h in a three-electrode configuration, and extended durability at 200 mA cm−2 for 450 h in a PEMWE. These findings underscore the strong dependence of catalytic activity and reaction pathways on the Co site configuration in Co-based metal oxide catalysts. To enhance OER performance, researchers are exploring innovative approaches to optimize the structure and composition of the catalyst to shift from AEM/LOM to OPM. This shift is designed to facilitate higher catalytic activity and stability. Additionally, novel OER mechanisms, including the proton donor-acceptor mechanism (PDAM) and the dioxygen radical coupling mechanism (DOM), are being investigated through advanced catalyst engineering. These strategies aim to stabilize reactive intermediates and enable alternative reaction pathways, ultimately improving catalytic efficiency and performance in acidic OER environments. 2.3.1 Oxide path mechanism In the OPM, O2 is generated through the direct coupling of two surface oxygen atoms (O*), which is an energy-saving process compared with the AEM pathway. Besides, the OPM avoids the OL taking part in the reactions and benefits from maintaining the structural integrity of the catalyst, contributing to its stability over extended operation. Although the OPM can be seen in the Co3O4 in alkaline and neutral media [118,119], it usually conducts the AEM pathway in an acidic environment [120]. To optimize the reaction pathway, the Ruarray-Co3O4 matrix was designed and synthesized via a calcination process of a mixture Co(NO3)2 and RuCl3, following a thermal-driven cation exchange strategy. Ruarray-Co3O4 matrix displayed near-ideal Ru–Ru interatomic distances and a unique Ru–O hybridization state, facilitating direct O*–O* radical coupling, and avoiding the OL participation thus increasing the activity and preventing active Ru dissolution [121]. As shown in Fig. 13 (a), aberration-corrected HAADF-STEM analysis demonstrated that Ru atoms were well-dispersed within the Co3O4 lattice with no aggregation. Fourier transform-EXAFS analysis further confirmed the absence of Ru–Ru coordination signals in Ruarray-Co3O4, and showed a Ru–O coordination state with the interatom distance of 1.44 Å (Fig. 13b). The Ruarray-Co3O4 electrocatalyst effectively overcame the typical activity-stability trade-off observed in RuO2-based catalysts, achieving a low OER overpotential of just 160 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in 0.5 M H2SO4, along with outstanding durability over 1500 h, positioning it as one of the most effective acid-stable OER electrocatalysts reported to date (Fig. 13c). Attenuated total reflectance surface-enhanced infrared absorption spectroscopy (ATR-SEIRAS FTIR) revealed characteristic signals of O–O, Ru–O*–O*, and Ru–O*–O*–Ru species, indicating the involvement of the OPM in Ruarray-Co3O4 (Fig. 13d). Additionally, the energy barrier for the RDS for Ruarray-Co3O4 in the OPM was calculated to be 2.23 eV, significantly lower than the 2.67 eV barrier associated with the AEM pathway, confirming the enhanced reaction kinetics for conducting the OPM (Fig. 13e, f). Co3− x Ba x O4 was synthesized by doping Ba cations into Co3O4 via an electrodeposition method to promote the OPM for OER, thereby improving both the activity and stability [122,123]. The Co3− x Ba x O4 catalyst exhibited an overpotential of 278 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and demonstrated excellent stability over 110 h of continuous OER operation, maintaining a FE of 99% (Fig. 13g). After prolonged OER operation, the Co3− x Ba x O4 catalyst retained its structural integrity and elemental composition, with only a small amount of Co ions dissolved into the electrolyte (Fig. 13h). Furthermore, in situ XANES and EXAFS measurements at the Co K-edge revealed that Ba cation incorporation effectively shortened both the Co–Co and Co–O distances and enhanced the Co valence (Fig. 13i, j), which facilitated the OPM and promoted OH− adsorption on the catalyst surface. In situ synchrotron Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) spectroscopy further confirmed the OPM, showing O–O bond formation and a linearly bonded superoxo species (M–O–O), thus demonstrating the OPM in Co3− x Ba x O4 (Fig. 13k). To further enhance the activity and stability of Co3O4-based catalysts in acidic media, Sun et al. doped Mo (0.5 wt%) into Co3O4, which was synthesized by hydrothermal with a post-annealing process to modulate the reaction mechanism. The synthesized Mo-doped Co3O4, exhibiting numerous oxygen vacancies (VO-Mo x Co3− x O4), was characterized by a low valence of 2.72 for Co ions, as determined by XANES spectra (Fig. 14 a, b) [124]. The catalyst showed an overpotential of 420 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and displayed a Tafel slope of 102.5 mV dec−1 for the OER in acidic conditions, outperforming both Co3O4 and Ir/C catalysts (Fig. 14c). VO-Mo x Co3− x O4 also exhibited high stability, maintaining performance for approximately 30 h at 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 14d). The Mo doping donated electrons to the Co sites, preventing Co dissolution at high potentials in acidic electrolytes, while also lowering the coordination number and reducing the Co–O bond length, which favored the OPM pathway. In situ FTIR spectra confirmed the OPM for VO-Mo x Co3− x O4, showing the formation of –O–O–, –O–O, and *OH intermediates (Fig. 14e). Additionally, DFT calculations revealed that the modification of Co 3d and O 2p orbitals hindered the AEM, thereby promoting the OPM, which resulted in a shift in the RDS. The VO-Mo x Co3− x O4 catalyst exhibited a lower RDS energy barrier compared to Co3O4, with the OPM being proven to be more energetically favorable compared with AEM (Fig. 14f–i). 2.3.2 Proton donor-acceptor mechanism Recent research has explored innovative catalytic mechanisms to enhance both the performance and stability of OEM catalysts. For instance, Ru single atoms anchored on Co3O4 have been synthesized by hydrothermal with a post-annealing process to improve acidic OER by precisely controlling the anchoring sites. This modification enables a shift in the reaction mechanism from the LOM to the optimized PDAM [125]. As shown in Fig. 15 (a), Ru atoms can be anchored either along the (111) crystal plane of Co3O4 forming lattice-anchored (Ruanc) or surface-adsorbed (Ruads) sites. Among these, Ruanc-Co3O4 exhibited superior OER performance with an overpotential of 198 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and stability beyond 50 h, significantly outperforming Ruads-Co3O4 (Fig. 15b). Pre-OER redox features observed in Co3O4 revealed equilibria involving dimeric Co redox centers. In contrast, both Ruads-Co3O4 and Ruanc-Co3O4 exhibited minimal charge accumulation from the Co3+/Co4+ redox couple, highlighting the influence of Ru sites on catalytic activity (Fig. 15c). For Ruads-Co3O4, the oxidation current increased slightly at 1.4 V vs. RHE and sharply at 1.5 V vs. RHE, corresponding to the redox transition of surface proton-stabilized –OO(H) groups. However, Ruanc-Co3O4 displayed negligible redox activity prior to the onset of oxygen evolution, demonstrating a fully oxidized surface and a shift in the RDS, accompanied by a change in catalytic mechanism. The single Ru atoms generated a localized Ru 4d-O 2p hybridized electronic state near the Fermi energy level, which facilitated charge transfer directly involved in the surface reactions, thereby enhancing reactivity (Fig. 15d). Furthermore, Ru–O–Co interactions altered charge distribution and surface adsorption behavior. As shown in Fig. 15(e), Co–O hybridization in Ruanc-Co3O4 was farther from the Fermi energy level, making valence electron loss at Co sites less favorable and suppressing the electrochemical release of lattice oxygen. Based on these findings, the authors proposed an optimized PDAM mechanism in Ruanc-Co3O4, establishing a novel single-atom catalytic pathway that circumvents the conventional scaling relationship inherent to the AEM and LOM. In Ruanc-Co3O4, the active center transitions from planar to three-dimensional, facilitating proton transfer from oxygen intermediates to neighboring bridging oxygen sites and enabling independent optimization of the reaction intermediates' binding energy (Fig. 15f). This work highlights a groundbreaking approach for tailoring single-atom catalysts to achieve enhanced catalytic performance and stability. 2.3.3 Dioxygen radical coupling mechanism The investigation of OER mechanisms not only enriches understanding of catalytic processes but also lays a critical foundation for designing high-performance catalysts for PEMWEs. Developing materials with optimized reaction pathways could significantly boost both the activity and durability of these catalysts. In this context, Zhu et al. proposed a novel strategy to enhance the activity and stability of Co3O4 in acidic OER conditions. This approach involves selectively substituting Ru atoms at octahedral Co sites in Co3O4, which was synthesized by a simple electrodeposition method followed by calcination in air, via a cation exchange strategy, thereby optimizing the DOM pathway for OER [126]. Co3O4 exhibited five Raman-active modes (A1g, Eg, and three F2g modes, as shown in Fig. 16 a). The Raman peaks of RuCoO x closely resembled those of Co3O4, but the peaks shifted to higher frequencies, with the A1g mode (685 cm−1) showing a more pronounced shift than the F2g mode (195 cm−1). This shift indicated a preferential substitution of Ru at octahedral (Cooct) sites over tetrahedral (Cotet) sites. Additionally, the reduced intensity of the A1g/F2g bands in RuCoO x suggested a lower Cooct/Cotet ratio due to Ru substitution at octahedral sites. A characteristic peak at 2.49 Å observed for the RuCoO x in the second shell in Ru Fourier transform-EXAFS spectra confirmed that Ru atoms successfully substitute partial Cooct sites in the Co3O4 (Fig. 16b). The substitution modulated the charge of oxygen-bridging Cooct atoms, reducing it from +1.23 to +1.18, while slightly altering neighboring Cooct sites and leaving Cotet sites largely unaltered (Fig. 16c, d). LSV revealed that RuCoO x required an overpotential of only 200 mV to achieve a current density of 10 mA cm−2, significantly lower than that of RuO2 (265 mV) and Co3O4 (409 mV) (Fig. 16e). Additionally, RuCoO x exhibited the lowest geometric Tafel slope among the three catalysts (Fig. 16f), indicating that Ruoct-O-Cooct coordination improved acidic OER kinetics. Remarkably, RuCoO x demonstrated exceptional stability, maintaining operation for over 100 h with an average degradation rate of only 0.45 mV h−1. Its acidic OER performance, characterized by minimal potential decay and low noble metal mass loading, surpassed that of various high-performance Ru-based catalysts (Fig. 16g). Furthermore, the average metal dissolution rate of RuCoO x during stability testing was significantly lower than that of RuO2 and Co3O4, being approximately 1/3 and 1/30, respectively. RuCoO x followed a unique DOM pathway driven by Ruoct-O-Cooct units, involving the adsorption of *OH intermediates, subsequent dehydrogenation, and final coupling of dioxygen radical (Fig. 16h), extensively studied in theoretical and experimental contexts. This work highlighted the potential of RuCoO x as a highly efficient and stable catalyst for acidic OER, driven by its unique structural and electronic properties. 3 Conclusions Developing efficient and stable OER catalysts for acidic environments remains a formidable challenge but holds vast potential for propelling advancements in hydrogen production through PEMWE. This review highlights substantial progress in the design of Co-based catalysts, which emerge as promising alternatives to their precious metal-based counterparts. Several strategies have been identified to bolster the activity and stability of Co-based catalysts. One approach is to enhance corrosion resistance and active surface area by incorporating small amounts of noble or other corrosion-resistant metals, such as Mn and La, into Co-based nanomaterials or by dispersing catalysts onto acid-resistant supports. Another effective strategy is to improve intrinsic structural stability and active site efficiency through structural optimization by the construction of heterojunctions or by leveraging combinations of multiple elements, up to HEMs. Moreover, refining the understanding and optimization of reaction pathways has laid a foundation for enhancing both catalytic activity and durability. Collectively, these advancements provide a promising framework for the continued development of high-performance OER catalysts tailored for acidic environments. 4 Challenges and solutions Developing cobalt-based catalysts for acidic oxygen evolution remains an active research frontier due to their potential as cost-effective alternatives to Ir- or Ru-based materials. Nevertheless, several formidable challenges continue to impede their industrial translation. 4.1 Scalability Most high-performance Co-based OER catalysts have been synthesized using laboratory-scale methods to enable precise control over morphology and composition, they typically suffer from low throughput and limited compatibility with industrial electrode architectures. To overcome these limitations, scalable synthetic strategies should be prioritized to enable gram-scale production. In practical device integration, these catalysts are typically dispersed in solvents with Nafion binders and deposited onto commercial substrates such as carbon paper, titanium felt, or porous metal foams via spray coating or drop-casting methods. These techniques are relatively straightforward and well-suited for preparing small-area electrodes (e.g., 5 cm × 5 cm), offering good control over catalyst loading and uniformity.
