However, when scaling up to larger electrode areas required for industrial applications with >1 m2 as the target in 2050 [127], these methods may present several challenges, including non-uniform catalyst distribution, poor mechanical adhesion, and inconsistent thickness across the substrate. Therefore, for large-area fabrication, more advanced deposition techniques—such as roll-to-roll printing, screen printing or electrodeposition—may be required to ensure uniformity, scalability, and long-term stability. Beyond ink-based deposition, in situ or direct growth of Co-based catalysts on conductive substrates is another way to enhance contact between the active material and the current collector, reduce interfacial resistance, and eliminate binder-related degradation [128–130], which also facilitates vertical alignment or hierarchical porosity, promoting gas bubble release and ionic diffusion under high-current conditions. 4.2 Stability at high current density As shown in Tables S1 and S3, Co-based catalysts still exhibit lower activity and stability compared with noble metal Ir- and Ru-based catalysts, typically lasting for several hundred hours due to the rapid dissolution and structural degradation, which still falls short of the industrial requirement of thousands of hours. To further enhance the performance and durability of Co-based catalysts in practical PEMWE systems, several strategic directions can be considered. Material-level modifications are essential. This includes doping Co with acid-stable or redox-stable elements to improve both the intrinsic activity and corrosion resistance under harsh acidic and oxidative conditions. The structural engineering of catalyst layers—such as designing nanostructured Co-based catalysts with robust supports can effectively suppress catalyst dissolution and enhance electrical conductivity while maintaining high surface areas. Encapsulation strategies, such as forming protective yet permeable shells (e.g., carbon, oxide layers) can mitigate ion leaching and preserve catalytic integrity during long-term operation. Beyond catalyst design, optimizing the catalyst-membrane interface is crucial, as interfacial delamination and proton transport bottlenecks are common degradation pathways in PEMWE. Strategies like functionalizing the ionomer or improving the distribution of proton-conducting phases within the catalyst layer can significantly enhance interfacial stability and reduce resistance. Furthermore, leached metal ions may migrate across the membrane, leading to undesirable effects such as membrane discoloration, swelling, and mechanical degradation, ultimately compromising the long-term durability of PEMWE systems [131–133]. At the device level, membrane protection strategies—including the incorporation of cation-exchange protective layers or the implementation of cation trap layers at the catalyst/membrane interface—could be an effective strategy to suppress ion migration and prolong the membrane operational lifetime. System-level approaches, such as developing corrosion-resistant bipolar plates to minimize metal ion contamination, optimizing cell architecture to ensure uniform water distribution and effective thermal management, and implementing advanced water management strategies to prevent membrane dehydration or electrode flooding, are also critical for enhancing the overall performance and durability of PEMWE systems. In summary, a multi-scale approach—encompassing catalyst composition, nanostructure engineering, interfacial design, and system optimization—is needed to overcome the degradation challenges and realize the long-term, high-performance application of Co-based catalysts in PEMWE systems. 4.3 Commercial and industrial feasibility Currently, Co-based catalysts and other transition metal catalysts are predominantly confined to laboratory research, with limited application in PEMWE devices. Although noble-metal-free Co-based catalysts show great promise in academic studies, their long-term stability, especially in membrane-integrated devices, remains insufficient to fully displace Ir/Ru-based counterparts (Tables S1–S3). Nevertheless, their low cost, earth abundance, and electronic tunability make them ideal for hybrid systems or partial substitution strategies. Therefore, there is a pressing need to scale up catalyst synthesis and evaluate performance in practical electrolysis cells, which could facilitate the transition from lab-scale to industrial applications, thus enhancing the commercial viability of these materials. 5 Future development directions To accelerate the industrial deployment of Co-based OER catalysts in acidic environments, future research should focus on several interlinked directions. First, the development of scalable and environmentally benign synthesis methods will be essential to achieve gram-to-kilogram production with controlled morphology and minimal post-treatment. Simultaneously, rational multimetallic design offers a pathway to synergistically enhance both catalytic activity and corrosion resistance by integrating self-limiting protective shells. Artificial intelligence and high-throughput screening platforms hold great promise for accelerating composition optimization by predicting stable and active material combinations based on large datasets and electronic structure descriptors. Employing advanced in-situ and ex-situ characterization techniques such as TEM, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), XAS, Raman, FTIR, and mass spectrometry (MS) is crucial for exploring catalyst behavior during reactions. Additionally, computational methods like DFT and finite element analysis can further aid in predicting and understanding these reaction/deactivation mechanisms. Electrode fabrication methods should be optimized by employing techniques like spray coating, electrophoretic deposition, or direct in situ growth on industrial Ti/stainless steel mesh/FTO substrates, which improve electrode compactness, electrical conductivity, and operational stability. At the device level, advancing surface engineering and membrane protection is essential for enhancing long-term stability. Designing interfacial buffer layers between the membrane and catalyst can effectively inhibit the migration of Co ions, thereby preventing membrane degradation and prolonging operational lifespan. Establishing standardized benchmarking protocols—including durability testing at industrially relevant current densities, dissolution tracking, and dynamic cycling performance—will ensure fair comparisons and facilitate industrial adoption. Collectively, these efforts will be crucial for translating Co-based OER catalysts from laboratory innovation to commercial application. He was as a postdoctoral fellow in Professor Xiaoqing Huang’s group at Xiamen University (2021–2023). Then he joined the School of Materials Science and Engineering, Jinan University. His research focus on the design of nanomaterial structures and the exploration of the structure-activity relationship between nanomaterial structure and its electrocatalytic performance. Jia Wang is currently a doctoral student at the Graduate School of Integrated Sciences for Life of Hiroshima University under the supervision of Prof. Atsuhiko Ishida. Her research focuses on the studies of carbonylation of CaM kinase phosphatase (CaMKP/PPM1F/POPX2) by polyphenols and its physiological effects. Ren He obtained his Ph.D. degree at Barcelona University (Spain) under the supervision of Prof. Andreu Cabot. Now he works at the Catalonia Institute for Energy Research (IREC) as a postdoctoral fellow. His current research mainly focuses on the design and synthesis of high entropy materials, with the application of oxygen catalysis, zinc-air batteries and lithium-sulfur batteries. Linlin Yang received her Ph.D. degree at the University of Barcelona. Now, she is a postdoctoral researcher on transition metal oxides electrocatalysts and their application in zinc-air batteries in Catalonia Institute for Energy Research (IREC), Spain. Yizhong Lu is currently a full professor in the School of Materials Science and Engineering, University of Jinan. He received his Ph.D. from Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, in 2015. He then worked as a research fellow in the School of Chemical and Biomedical Engineering, NTU. His research interests include design, synthesis, and electrocatalytic applications of nanomaterials for fuel cells and water splitting. Andreu Cabot is ICREA research professor at the Catalonia Institute for Energy Research (IREC), Spain. He received his PhD from the University of Barcelona in 2003. From 2004 to 2007, he worked as a postdoctoral researcher in Prof. A. Paul Alivisatos group at the University of California at Berkeley and the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory. His main research interests include the design and engineering of nanoparticles and nanomaterials, the characterization of their functional properties, their use for the manufacturing of scaffolds and electrodes, and their application in energy conversion and storage.

coredata.dc:description: Proton exchange membrane water electrolyzers (PEMWEs) are pivotal for efficient hydrogen production due to their high energy efficiency and ability to operate at high current densities, making them ideally suited for integration with renewable energy sources. Cobalt (Co)-based nanomaterials, characterized by diverse oxidation states, tunable electronic spin states, and hybrid orbitals, have emerged as promising non-noble metal alternatives to platinum group catalysts for accelerating the anodic oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Based on their inherent properties, this review provides a comprehensive overview of the latest developments in Co-based nanomaterials for acidic OER. The review begins by introducing the operational principles of PEMWEs, the underlying catalytic mechanisms, and the critical design considerations for OER catalysts. It then explores strategies to enhance the activity and stability of Co-based catalysts for acidic OER in PEMWEs, including the incorporation of corrosion-resistant metals or dispersion on acid-resistant supports to increase active surface area and stability; utilization of geometric structural engineering to improve structural integrity and active site efficiency; the optimization of reaction mechanisms to fine-tune catalytic pathways for enhanced stability and performance. The performance degradation mechanisms and metal leaching analysis for Co-based catalysts in PEMWE are also clarified. Finally, this review not only outlines the key challenges associated with Co-based catalysts for acidic OER but also proposes potential strategies to overcome these limitations, offering a roadmap for future advancements and practical implementation of PEMWE technology.
